FREN 351 Media and Genre (Prof. Tsobgny MW 2:30-3:45pm in person)
Content:  This course presents topics in French and Francophone studies through diverse media and genres in order to foster critical thinking through specific analysis. 
Taught in French, the course will put water at the center of a study to review various problems related to this matter (access to drinking water, drought, flooding, pollution, global warming, etc.). We will explore water issues as a key to understanding human cultures and human relationships with the environment. The study of water issues offers an interesting opportunity to engage in an interdisciplinary inquiry since water is essential in human life and functioning of human societies. Our study will focus on the intersection of environmental issues and culture, industrialization, economic inequity, environmental injustice, social injustice, postcolonial economy, and racism. Students will develop a vocabulary for thinking and talking about the explored themes. We will also analyze the role of art in the struggle for environmental issues.


Learning Objectives: describe studied environmental and ecological concepts;
critically analyze and debate environmental issues; examine lifestyle issues and critically analyze the relationships between population, natural resources, land use, industrialization, and pollution; develop a broad understanding of the place of humans in the nature and evaluate practices of humans as they interact with their environment; develop knowledge and skills to work toward solutions to environmental problems; develop skills that showcase an integrated adaptation of new vocabulary and new ideas.
Particulars
Active participation, CANVAS short responses, 1 oral presentation, 2 papers (3 pages each).
